WRITING.TITLE: A lamb attempt
WRITING.TEXT: I'm a complete beginner, I have been curing only in my fridge. Recently I bought a wine fridge to use as a curing chamber(after this has been made). This is my attempt at curing some lamb. I took a few lamb leg chops from the shop, cleaned them from the fats and 2 chops resulted in 4 small pieces. #8203; https://preview.redd.it/fo16zgvuc5i21.jpg?width=3024 amp;format=pjpg amp;auto=webp amp;s=56c4faecbd97a74fe03fb4d7bd08981b9dd447cd https://preview.redd.it/qf7x6hvuc5i21.jpg?width=3024 amp;format=pjpg amp;auto=webp amp;s=5a2abb2cb7791eafdda10382f14d1511ff2ff6a6 I didn't document my recipe very well, however, this is more or less it: 30 hrs in fine sea salt 10-15 hrs in water Seasoning (including some I brought from Eastern Europe): * Salt * Black Pepper * Red pepper * Lovage ( #1076; #1077; #1074; #1077; #1089; #1080; #1083;) * Savory ( #1095; #1091; #1073; #1088; #1080; #1094; #1072;)

Ended up quite salty actually. All my relatives who cure meat at home use coarse sea salt, so with my next batch I'm trying to determine whether that was the reason for saltiness. It's coarse, but it's also less salt and I turned them around once or twice. Other than that, the spices complement the flavour quite well. It's also quite soft, i.e. I did not dry it for too long! Surprising thing - I think it was drying faster in my regular fridge compared to my wine cooler, which uses thermoelectric cooling and has a fan because of that. It's also working at 10 degrees, while my regular fridge is surely lower. I expected this to be the other way around :D ! I haven't cut the other pieces though, so it just might seem that way on the outside.

On top of that, a lot of my spells require the opponent to be able to hear me, this has already bitten me in the ass multiple times. My only damaging cantrip is viscous mockery. I believe the solution of the problem might be to get some other cantrip which does some other type of damage and I can see a few options 1. Change my Half-Elf to a High half-elf variant, which would let me choose a cantrip and I can get something like firebolt or Ray of frost or idk 1. Pros: don't lose much, a couple of proficiencies which right now are Arcana, Perception and Performance. 2. Cons: The hit bonus is +3 as opposed to +7 if I get eldritch blast via other means. Toll the dead is 10 WIS save. I've got no idea why 2. Give up my Ability Score improvement from level 4 and take the spell sniper feat, which will give me Eldritch blast 1. Pros: I get access to eldritch blast, which I don't have with the aforementioned option 2. Cons: Will have lower Charisma, which means my saves drop to 14, instead of 15. 3. At level 6 college of Lore lets me choose any 2 spells and add them to my list of spells. Cons: If I chose one of the other options, I could still choose a cool spell from other class' spell list with this. 4. Multiclass into Warlock for, say, 2 levels - maybe Archfey or Hexblade 1. WRITING.TITLE: Should I expect a bottle bomb?
WRITING.TEXT: Hey everyone, looking for advice - I may have made a mistake and now I'm paranoid. I was making a banana wheat beer - got a packet of young's wheat extract, a few bananas and chugged them in my \~5L glass carboy. I left a reasonable amount of headspace, but fermentation was quite vigorous and it spat bananas out of the airlock and I had a leak and a small mess. Cleaned up, added new bananas, put a blow off tube and... to my surprise, the fermentation was still vigorous enough to keep pushing bananas and foam out through the blow off tube. After 6 or 7 days it was already calm and I thought there's no way it's still fermenting, so I bottled with a little bit of sugar to carbonate - I use a measuring cup, it always gets the carbonation perfect. However, only then I decided to measure gravity with what was left that didn't fit in a full bottle. WRITING.TITLE: Question about initiating combat
WRITING.TEXT: I'm a newb DM and I was running the one shot "A wild sheep chase" for my friends. The situation was the following: A sheep, that is actually a polymorphed wizard, finds the party - in this case in a tavern, holds a scroll of speak with animals and explains to them its situation. While it's talking, a half orc with two wolves and a hooded figure enters the tavern and tries to take the sheep. The half-orc doesn't jump to the fight right away but doesn't waste his time talking either. In our case he came into the tavern, said he wants his sheep back and while walking towards the wizard and the sheep, the wizard cast fog cloud. This essentially initiates combat, her attempt was to use it to avoid the fight and escape. I wasn't sure how to rule that, so I said she casts fog cloud and then we roll initiative - i.e. she doesn't get her movement. Thanks! #8203; Edit: Thank you so much for all the answers! I think I boil it down to 3 options. 1. The party gets a surprise round 2. We roll initiative, the half-orc wins, notices the caster, but just goes before the wizard manages to cast the spell 3. We roll initiative, everything is as normal, but the wizard is automatically on top. I imagine all 3 are up to DM's discretion, I believe in this case the last one makes most sense, because the other party members were at the bar at that time, so a surprise round for all members doesn't make sense. A surprise round only for the wizard doesn't make too much sense either, because if she wins initiative this means she would go twice, but the others were ready for combat as well, just hadn't initiated.

I found myself trying to replicate a wine-like flavour when I'm making mead - e.g. I'm looking for some tartness and acidity and not that much sweetness. Naturally, I went with fruits like blueberries, blackberries, and in those I actually found that cheaper honey goes better, because it doesn't leave that much of a honey flavour afterwards. My blueberry mead came out quite sweet tasting, next time I'm doing one I'm squeezing more lemon juice(I might have not squeezed any this time) and possibly oaking it. I've had some forest fruit meads that came out great with a lot of fruit flavour using cheap honey. #8203; Now if you actually want those honey flavours to stay - especially if going with traditional or lightly spiced, then quality will make a big difference. At the very least I'd suggest, before buying in bulk, buy a single jar/bottle of the honeys you're interested in and taste them, that will give you a pretty good guide on what their difference in quality is - it might actually turn out that they all taste basically the same and there's no point in getting the more expensive honey. Lastly, I'm gonna say... experiment - make a mead with cheap honey, make a mead with expensive and get to know the honeys you prefer - at the end of the day.. it's all about experimentation and trying out different combinations.
